ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Introduction---recurrency question
ygData.msgSnippet: Ken, I don t know if Jeff is calling a ANN with recurrent connections, static or not.  If he means the network is static topologically, then he could be

Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Introduction---recurrency question
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=82117382; y=Eh1QVM2MsqxKYJe3QUUdeJ5NF_dy_PTb2rtiORTqfMtf0dEYKQjGKW3f3g
X-Yahoo-Profile: jim_oflaherty_jr

Ken,

I don't know if Jeff is calling a ANN with recurrent connections, static 
or not.  If he means the network is static topologically, then he could 
be including recurrence.  If by static, he means feedforward only, no 
recurrence...then I would disagree with his initial assertion as it 
would preclude circuits holding state from some previous "context" and 
applying it to the current "context".

 From what I have been able to see, a standard feedforward network is 
just a state machine.  Precisely the same input will result in precisely 
the same output.  And without recurrence, the ANNs I have seen 
implemented with NEAT behave essentially the same as a standard 
feedforward network.  It is essentially the equivalent of a ROM, Read 
Only Memory.  Some very fascinating things can be done with process and 
ROM.  However, the one thing that cannot be accomplished is any form of 
dynamic state management upon which *my* understanding of the word 
"learning" depends (at least withing a single "specimen" of an 
evolutionary run).

With recurrence, things substantially change.  With any degree of 
recurrence, the network is very unlikely to provide precisely the same 
output for precisely the same input.  The network is no longer a pure 
state machine.  Here it is like a ROM with some RAM (recurrent 
connections are a form of memory), albeit the Random part of Random 
Access Memory is inaccurate.

So, Jeff - Does your definition of a "static neural network" include 
recurrence?


Jim


Kenneth Stanley wrote:

> I'm not sure I follow this logic.  A computer isn't just made out of
> NAND gates.  It also has flip-flops for storing data.  Therefore, I
> don't think it follows that a feedforward neural network can act as
> a programmable computer.
>
> ken
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff Haynes" <jeff@d...> wrote:
> > Well, I'm sure people are getting weary of hearing us go on about
> this
> > particular topic so I'll just say one last thing on it.
> >
> > - One can recreate any arbitrary circuit with a static neural
> network (in case
> > there is any doubt about this, try creating a NAND gate).
> >
> > - Therefore, one can recreate a computer with a neural network.
> > - A computer can be programmed to learn.
> > - Therefore, a static neural network can learn.
> >
> > Unless there is some error in that logic, I'm not sure what the
> real issue is.
> >  If we could refrain from talking about nebulous concepts like
> constructive
> > signal reinforcement in the brain, that would really make this
> easier for me
> > too.  Thanks, regards,
> >
> > jeff
>
>
>
>
